For my position (Order Fulfillment Rep), you're basically customer service for the factory in your city. You communicate with Foxconn's customers globally using a website called Salesforce.Within Salesforce, customers create cases where they request various needs like:- Expediting orders- Providing the status of orders- Informing managers in releasing "holds" on products (holds prevent the order from being built by your production team)- Scheduling orders- Making sure the orders go through the system. If not, you need to talk to your IT team to fix the "signal" issue so that the order can appear in both ends (customer and you).Overtime, you get to learn which customer belongs to which company, the products they use, and also learning the process of the overall workflow of the factory.When I started my job with Foxconn last June in the year of 2014, my team was composed of 4 people. Now, that has shrunk down to 1 (which is me). People leave because the job can be stressful, but it is rewarding in the end.Apart from networking with your co-workers in the office, you also get to network with your customers. Who knows, you get to work for them ~

At 8 am we had the breakfast break for 15-20 minutes depending on the quota we had to fill. After the break we checked the quota to make sure we are on track. At 12 pm we had another 30-45 minutes break. After this break we checked quota again and redistribute some tasks if needed. At 3pm we had a 15 minutes break and we used that to make some extra work to be able to leave  earlier. At 6 pm we had to go back home. Another day at work has finished. I learned to be time efficient, and a good team leader for the rest of the guys. The hardest part of the job was when the quota was so big that we had to bring some new guys to help us out with some duties. The most enjoyable part of the job was when we managed to fill the quota, without any accidents, even if the quota was very big sometimes.

Most of the office is still there past 6 pm. Each person will have at least two bosses (functional and cell manager). The work life balance is probably the hardest when you first start. Several people quite before a year mark because of it. One function relys on the other to complete your work. One weak team member may delay problem resolution or cause team to stay late. Most cell managers are not micro managers and will allow you to manage your own time. You can take a long lunch break as long as you can complete your work in timely manner. This gives time to get away with co-workers and enjoy your lunch without rushing back. If you stick around you will learn alot at this company because one function must understand what the other function is doing in order to communicate with customer in unison. My typical day starts around 5:30am each morning.  After a quick gathering of clothing, I would head toward a gym for a 45 minute workout.  The energy boost from the workout would last me all day.I get to work between 7:30am and 8:00am in most mornings.  Typically, there were a list of standard tasks to do: read a few dashboard manufacturing reports from the previous nights, login the server and download the upcoming orders and review the production plans against them.Once I have a clear idea of what needs to happen that day, I would take a look at my daily schedule and weekly reminders of the upcoming events.  Almost half of my days are scheduled with inter-department meetings.  For those meetings require my input, I typically would have them prepared before the meeting.Since my position involves dealing with Production, Production Control, Material Control, Engineering, Planning, and Program Management, they are the people I go to the most.  Interaction with them are critical each day because there is always something that would happen in manufacturing.The toughest part about the job is not knowing all the information before I had to make a decision.  I would be more confident once all facts are known, but that is not always a luxury I could have.The most enjoyable part of the job would that satisfaction at the end of the day knowing everything I set out to do that day is done.  I could go home and enjoy the night.Oh, that 5:30am wake-up call means an energy crash right round lunch time.
